docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, April 8, 7:05 p.m. | Thomas G. Andrews, a historian and author of "Killing for Coal," joins the discussion.

headline.main: Why Do We Still Have Mining Disasters?

docs.abstract: Why, after such a long history of injury and death, does coal mining remain so dangerous?
docs.snippet: Why, after such a long history of injury and death, does coal mining remain so dangerous?

docs.lead_paragraph: As attention shifts from passage of health care legislation to its implementation, we will take the next few weeks to answer readers' questions here in Prescriptions. Submit your question to health_feedback@nytimes.com. You may also submit videos. Please remember that we cannot respond to all questions and that we cannot offer personal advice.

headline.main: How Much Will the High-Risk Pools Cost?

docs.abstract: The high-risk insurance pools to begin this year should offer consumers significant improvements over current state-sponsored pools.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: There are signs consumers are spending again, new fees for large carry-on bags and other consumer-focused items from Wednesday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chief appeals court that oversees federal regulations delivered a body blow to the Federal Communications Commission by ruling that the agency lacks the explicit statutory authority to require that Internet service providers treat all customers and Web sites equally, regardless of how much or what kind of information they download or deliver.

headline.main: The Early Word: The Bandwidth Plays On

docs.abstract: A federal court limits the Federal Communications Commission's powers to regulate the Internet.
docs.snippet: A federal court limits the Federal Communications Commission's powers to regulate the Internet.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation. According to a criminal complaint, the man, Charles A. Wilson, 64, of Selah, Wash., made a series of threatening phone calls to Senator Murray's Seattle office between March 22 -- the day after Congress approved the health care law -- and April 4, including a recorded message in which he said, ''I want to kill you.''

headline.main: Threats to Kill Senator Lead to Arrest

docs.abstract: Charles A Wilson is arrested and charged with threatening to kill Washington Sen Patty Murray; Wilson made several threatening phone calls to Murray's office because he was angry about her vote in favor of major health care legislation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Federal agents on Tuesday arrested and charged a man with threatening to kill Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, because he was angry about her vote in favor of the major health care legislation.     According to a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait seems puzzled by a Michael Barone column in which Barone can't imagine that a key part of the Obama stimulus plan, aid to state governments, had any purpose other than to reward unionized government workers. Chait's puzzlement made me think of Ezra Klein's somewhat similar puzzlement over a column by Shelby Steele, in which Steele attributed Obama's push for health care reform to "grandiosity" and "narcissism" -- never once mentioning that Obama might have, well, wanted to cover the uninsured.
docs.abstract: Incomprehension, demonization, and the closing of the conservative mind.
docs.snippet: Incomprehension, demonization, and the closing of the conservative mind.

docs.lead_paragraph: The secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, wrote to state officials on Tuesday to urge that they take action against "scam artists" reportedly marketing fake insurance policies to exploit the new law overhauling the health care system.

headline.main: Health Secretary Warns of Insurance Scams

docs.abstract: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, urged state officials to take action against "scam artists" reportedly marketing fake insurance policies to exploit the new law overhauling the health care system.
docs.snippet: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, urged state officials to take action against "scam artists" reportedly marketing fake insurance policies to exploit the new law overhauling the health care system.
